name: Centroid Theorem
statement: The medians of a triangle intersect at a single point called the centroid.
formal: The three medians of triangle ABC are concurrent at point G (the centroid).
philosophy: The centroid is the average of the triangle's vertices and lies on all three medians.

name: Euler Line Theorem
statement: In any non-equilateral triangle, the centroid, circumcenter, and orthocenter are collinear.
formal: Points G (centroid), O (circumcenter), and H (orthocenter) lie on a line (Euler line).
philosophy: A deep alignment of triangle centers along a single line. Fundamental for synthetic geometry.

name: Incenter via Angle Bisectors
statement: The incenter of a triangle lies at the intersection of its angle bisectors.
formal: Angle bisectors of triangle ABC are concurrent at I (incenter).
philosophy: The incenter is equidistant from the triangle's sides. Its existence relies on concurrency of bisectors.

name: Circumcenter via Perpendicular Bisectors
statement: The perpendicular bisectors of a triangle’s sides intersect at the circumcenter.
formal: Perpendicular bisectors of triangle ABC are concurrent at O (circumcenter).
philosophy: The circumcenter is equidistant from the triangle's vertices and exists by bisector concurrency.

name: Collinearity by Zero Area
statement: Three points are collinear if and only if the area of the triangle they form is zero.
formal: Area(A, B, C) = 0 ⇔ A, B, C collinear
philosophy: A general and coordinate-agnostic way to check collinearity using geometric invariants.
